sections.heading: Abstract
sections.text:
Recently, electromagnetic interference (EMI) shielding materials have absorbed a lot of attention due to a growing need for application in the area of electronic and wireless devices. In this study, a carbon-based EMI shielding composite was fabricated by electrophoretic deposition of Fe3O4 nano-particles on carbon fibers (CFs) as a 3D structure incorporated with an epoxy resin. Coprecipitation method was employed to synthesize Fe3O4 nano-particles. This as-synthesized Fe3O4 nano-powder was then successfully deposited on CFs using a modified multi-step electrophoretic deposition (EPD) method. The results of structural studies showed that the Fe3O4 nano-particles (25 nm) were successfully and uniformly deposited on CFs. The measured magnetic properties of as-synthesized Fe3O4 nano-powder and nano-Fe3O4/CFs composite showed that the saturation magnetization of bare Fe3O4 was decreased from Ms=72.3 emu/g to Ms=33.1 emu/g for nano-Fe3O4/CFs composite and also corecivity of Fe3O4 was increased from

The results of microwave absorption tests revealed that the reflection loss (RL) of an epoxy-based nano-Fe3O4/CFs composite are significantly influenced by layer thickness. The maximum RL value of -10.21 dB at 10.12 GHz with an effective absorption bandwidth about 2 GHz was obtained for the sample with the thickness of 2 mm. It also exhibited an EMI shielding performance of -23 dB for whole the frequency range of 8.2-12.4 GHz.
Keywords: Electromagnetic interference shielding, Nano-Fe3O4 coated carbon fibers, Electrophoretic deposition, Magnetic materials.

sections.heading: 1. Introduction
sections.text:
Nowadays the electromagnetic interference (EMI) shielding materials have been the subject of many studies in the scope of advanced technologies such as satellite, television, local area network, wireless data communication, aerospace and etc. due to their ability in absorbing electromagnetic waves specially microwave signals by magnetic and dielectric loss mechanisms [1, 2]. Based on loss mechanisms, the MI shielding materials are categorized in two main groups of magnetic and dielectric materials. The most important properties of these materials, which play a key role in their applications, are weight and thickness [3, 4]. A simple and effective method for reducing the weight and thickness of EMI shielding materials is to use strong magnetic and dielectric materials together in one structure [5].
Fe3O4 nano-particles due to their higher microwave absorption properties are good candidates for magnetic atenuative sources in EMI shielding composites. Due to different applications of Fe3O4 nano-particles (for instance; in drug delivery, magnetic resonance imaging, EMI shielding, pigments and photocatalysis), the preparation techniques and characteristics methods of these
M AN
US CR
IP T
AC CE
PT ED
3
materials have been extensively studied [6]. Among different techniques which can be used for produce nano-Fe3O4, wet chemical methods, especially co-precipitation method due to their simple and cost effective procedures, have gained much attention in recent years [6, 7].
Despite the high magnetic loss of Fe3O4 nano-particles, it does not have any appropriate dielectric loss property in high efficiency EMI shielding applications. Therefore, carbon and carbon-based materials such as carbon fibers (CFs) [1-3], carbon nano-tubes (CNTs) [8, 9, 10], graphene [10-12] and graphene oxide (GO) [13,14], are good choices to be used alongside the magnetic materials in advanced microwave absorber composites due to their light weight and high dielectric losses.
Nowadays, some novel techniques have been used to fabricate carbon-based composites including wet chemical methods, for example, sol-gel [15], chemical vapor deposition (CVD) [16], hydrothermal process [17] and electrophoretic deposition (EPD) [18, 19, 23, 24]. Among these techniques, electrophoretic deposition (EPD) method has been chosen for fabrication of these nano-composites due to its low cost and ability in deposition of a wide range of metallic and ceramic particles on substrate. In EPD process, the thickness and morphology of deposited coatings can be tailored by adjusting the applied voltage and deposition time. In this process, by addition of a surfactant, the surface of particles are electrically charged so that they can be suspended in a liquid medium [20]. By applying a direct current between two electrodes, these charged particles based on the type of their surface charge, can be deposited either on the cathode or anode [20].
Recently, some researchers have coated CFs with Fe3O4 nano-particles via wet chemical techniques for microwave absorption applications [5, 21]. Salimkhani et al. deposited spherical

US CR
IP T
AC CE
PT ED

carbonyl iron particles on CFs, using EPD process. They reported that, the best microwave attenuation results of -13.8 dB was obtained at 11.5 GHz [18]. Osouli-Bostanabad et al. also deposited Fe3O4 on CFs by EPD process for similar application. The maximum reflection loss (RL) value reported in this work was -11 at 10.37 GHz and 11.4 GHz [23]. Salimkhani et al. reported the deposition of CoFe2O4 on CFs in another study, again using EPD process. They obtained a maximum microwave absorption value of -10.25 dB at 11.39 [24].
Considering the referred studies, it is found that, the better EMI shielding performance can be obtained by accurate selection of materials and optimizing the EPD parameters.
In this work, the physicochemical, structural, magnetic, microwave absorption and EMI shielding properties of nano-Fe3O4/CFs composites, which were fabricated by incorporating the Fe3O4-coated CFs (via a modified multi-step EPD process) with epoxy resin, are reported and analyzed.
2. Materials and methods
2.1. Materials
The acetone (99%), iodine (99.8%), FeCl3.6H2O (99.9%), ethanol (96%), ammonium hydroxide (33%) and nitric acid (65%) supplied by Merck company (Germany), pure FeSO4.7H2O supplied by Sigma Aldrich company (USA), carbon fibers (D=10 µ) supplied by Chongqing Joywell Trade company (China) Epoxy (Viscosity in 25 °C=1.75 MPa.S and Density in 25 °C =1150 kg/m3) and its hardener (Viscosity in 25 °C=1.1 MPa.S and Density in 25 °C =1000 kg/m3) were all purchased and were used without further purification.
2.2. Synthesis of nano-Fe3O4 particles
M AN
US CR
IP T
AC CE
PT ED
5
The simple and cost effective co-precipitation method was chosen to synthesize the Fe3O4 nanoparticles. All solutions were prepared in deionized water. To fabricate Fe3O4 nano-particles, 1 M aqueous FeSO4.7H2O (10 ml) solution with 1 M aqueous FeCl3.6H2O (20 ml) solution was mixed in a four neck flask under a nitrogen atmosphere in 60 °C for 15 minutes. Then, the temperature of solution increased to 80 °C and ammonium hydroxide (NH4OH) solution (about 30 ml) was slowly added with vigorous stirring until the pH of 12 was reached. Vigorous stirring was continued for another 45 minutes. The solution color could be seen altering from brown to black Fe3O4 nano-particles. The Fe3O4 nano-particles were separated by using a permanent external magnet. Deionized water was then added to beaker in order to centrifuge the particles. This step was repeated for 6 times to clean excessive ions and salts. Finally, particles were washed with ethanol and stored in a dry and clean vial [7].
2.3. Preparation of EPD suspension
The suspensions were prepared by dissolving 10 mg of iodine in 100 ml acetone and dispersion of 50 mg of as-synthesized Fe3O4 powder with a mechanical stirrer. After mechanically stirring for 15 min, in order to increase the stability and preventing agglomeration, the suspensions were dispersed ultrasonically for another 15 min. The temperature of suspensions was increased due to ultrasonic high energy waves, therefor in order to prevent volatilization of acetone the beaker was sealed by a paraffin foil.
2.4. Preparation of EPD electrodes
The pan-based carbon fibers (CFs) which were about 10 µm in diameter and 6 cm in length were used as the cathode of EPD process. The CFs were treated with nitric acid (65 wt. %) in order to
M AN
US CR
IP T
AC CE
PT ED
6
increase the interfacial bonding strength and then washed with deionized water and dried for 24 hours at 80 °C. A stainless of 316 L type thin foil was chosen as the anode of EPD process. To increase the uniformity of EPD coatings, the anode was shaped to a cylindrical tube with a diameter about 4 cm and a length of about 12 cm. Thereafter, cylindrical anode was placed in a beaker. The cathode was placed at the center of beaker and anode with a glass holder. The distance between the anode and cathode was set to be about 0.5 cm. A schematic of EPD setup is presented in Fig.1.
2.5. Electrophoretic deposition (EPD)
The EPD process was conducted using a direct current power supply with a constant voltage of 22.4 V. A current density of approximately 8 mA.cm-2 was measured throughout the EPD process. In order to increase the efficiency of process, all the CFs were electrophoretically coated twice. Each step of deposition process took 15 min. After EPD steps, all CFs were washed with acetone and deionized water to remove all agglomerated particles and heat treated for 2 hours at 60°C.
2.6. Characterizations
The structural studies and morphology of as-synthesized Fe3O4 nano-powder and nanoFe3O4/CFs composite were studied using transmission electron microscopy (TEM, Philips CM30, Netherlands), X-ray diffraction method (XRD, X’Pert MPD system, Philips, Netherlands, λCuKα1=0.154 nm) and scanning electron microscopy (SEM, Philips XL30, Netherlands). The chemical composition and structure of samples were studied using energy dispersive X-ray spectroscopy (EDX, which had been installed on the SEM apparatus) and Fourier transform
M AN
US CR
IP T
AC CE
PT ED
7
infrared spectroscopy (FT-IR, PerkinElmer Spectrum system, Netherlands). The magnetic properties of samples were investigated using vibrating sample magnetometer method (VSM, C300, Germany) at room temperature. The EM properties of composites were measured in the frequency range of 8.2–12.4 GHz using vector network analyzer device (VNA, HP 8720 Network Analyzer, USA) at room temperature. For VNA measurements, the coated CFs were cut into short fragments (2–3 mm in length), then 0.03 g of fragments were mixed with certain amount of epoxy resin by slow mechanical agitation. The weight ratio of CFs fragments to epoxy resin was 1:4. For the next step, the mixtures were casted into a rectangular mold with the dimension of 10.16 mm× 22.86 mm× 5 mm on a substrate with the same dimensions. In order to characterize the best microwave absorption performance, five samples with different thicknesses of 1 mm, 1.5 mm, 2 mm, 2.5 mm and 3 mm were fabricated.

As it can be seen from XRD pattern of as-synthesized powder in Fig. 2, the Fe3O4 powder has a spinel structure, which is in a good agreement with JCPDS, No. 19-0629. Hence it can be concluded that as-synthesized Fe3O4 powder was in a high level of purity and also due to the existence of sharp and strong peaks, it was well crystallized.
The TEM image of as-synthesized Fe3O4 powder is shown in Fig. 3. It is evident that, the average size of Fe3O4 particles is under 25 nm. In this way, the TEM observations prove the results of crystallite size calculations based on Scherer equation.
3.2. Mechanisms of EPD process
Fig. 4 shows the schematic illustration of EPD process of Fe3O4 nano-particles on the surface of CFs and the inverse spinel crystal structure of magnetite. Inverse spinel is a cubic close packed arrangement of oxygen ions in which the octahedral and tetrahedral sublattices are occupied by iron ions. There are also 3 more steps in Fig. 4. These steps are related to the surface charge of particles which is the key driving force for particles movement towards the cathode. For the step (1), the reaction of iodine with acetone can be written as the following reaction [21]. 2 + → + 2 + 2 (2) For the step (2), this reaction results in production of H+ ions. For the step 3, these cations stick to the surface of Fe3O4 nano-particles. Due to positive charge of H +, the suspended Fe3O4 nanoparticles can move through the suspension under the generated DC electrical field toward cathode which fully covers the CFs’ surface.
3.3. Phase and Morphology of nano-Fe3O4/CFs composite

The peaks indicated in XRD pattern of nano-Fe3O4/CFs composite (Fig. 2) may be attributed to magnetite and graphite phases of deposited Fe3O4 nano-particles and CFs. The sharp peak in 22° (scattering from (002) plane) and broadened peak around 26° could be related to the graphitic crystalline structure of CFs [25]. In addition, the other seven diffraction peaks at 2θ angles of 30.29°, 35.54°, 43.21°, 54.11°, 57.31°, 62.86° and 74.73° are characteristic peaks of spinel structure of deposited Fe3O4 powder which is associated with scattering from the (200), (220), (311), (400), (422), (511), (440) and (533) planes of the Fe3O4 crystal lattices, respectively. Therefore, the results of XRD studies confirm deposition of Fe3O4 nano-particles on CFs [22, 26].
Fig. 5 illustrates the SEM images and EDS spectra of Fe3O4 coated CFs. It is clear that the Fe3O4 nano-particles completely deposited and covered the surface of CFs. Furthermore, the presence of carbon, oxygen and iron peaks in the EDS spectra of Fig. 5 (d) confirms the results of XRD analyses and deposition of Fe3O4 nano-particles on the CFs.
3.4. Chemical properties of nano-Fe3O4/CFs composite
Due to the same crystal structure (reverse spinel crystal structure) of Fe3O4 and γ-Fe2O3, and also, due to their close lattice parameters (a=0.839 nm for Fe3O4 and a=0.835 nm for γ-Fe2O3), it is difficult to distinguish Fe3O4 peaks from γ-Fe2O3 ones only based on XRD patterns. In order to identify the main crystalline phase of as-synthesized Fe3O4 powder, more analyses are required [27]. To meet this requirement, FT-IR spectra of nano-Fe3O4/CFs composite is presented in Fig. 6. The peak at 583 cm-1 is assigned to the Fe-O stretching mode of the octahedral and tetrahedral sites of Fe3O4, while in FT-IR spectra of γ-Fe2O3, the absorbing peak appears at around 630 cm -1

3.6. Magnetic properties of as-synthesized Fe3O4 powder and nano-Fe3O4/CFs
composite
Fig. 7 demonstrates the schematic illustration of corecivity versus nano-particles size. Accordingly, there are two fundamental diameter values for nano-magnetic particles. The first one is the super paramagnetic diameter (Dsp) value. The particles with sizes smaller than Dsp are super paramagnetic. Due to insufficient energy absorption, the super paramagnetic particles are not good choices for EMI shielding applications. The second fundamental diameter is critical diameter (Dc) value in which the particles with smaller diameters than Dc, exhibit single domain

behavior. In single domain particles, the magnetic losses are generated due to magnetic spins rotation; while for particles with larger diameters (multi-domain particles), they are mostly generated by movement of domain walls [32, 33]. Due to appropriate microwave attenuation of single domain particles, unlike the super paramagnetic particles, they have been used in EMI shielding composites. The characterized region (red rectangular) in Fig. 7 illustrates the most appropriate size distribution of nano-particles for EMI shielding applications. In literature, the reported Dsp and Dc values for Fe3O4 are 13 nm and 34.5 nm, respectively [23, 32]. Therefore, due to the as-synthesized Fe3O4 particles size (25 nm) being bigger than Dsp and also smaller than Dc of Fe3O4, it is exactly placed in the appropriate region of particle size distribution (Fig. 7) as an EMI shielding material.
Fig. 8 shows the magnetic hysteresis loops of as-synthesized Fe3O4 and nano-Fe3O4/CFs composite. The saturation magnetization (Ms), corecivity (Hc) and residual magnetization (Mrs) values of as-synthesized Fe3O4 and nano-Fe3O4/CFs composite are listed in Table 2.

3.5. Permittivity and permeability characterizations of epoxy-based nano-
Fe3O4/CFs composite It is well known that the complex permeability and permittivity can be expressed as = ˊ − ˝ and = ˊ − ˝, the real part of complex permeability ( ˊ) indicates the energy storage of magnetic field and its imaginary part ( ˝) represents the ability of magnetic loss. Similarly, the real part ( ˊ) and imaginary part ( ˝) of the complex permittivity show the energy capacity of electric field and also the ability of dielectric losses, respectively. Fig. 9 shows the frequency dependence of the real and imaginary parts of complex permittivity and permeability, the magnetic tangent loss (tanδm=µ˝/µˊ) and also the dielectric tangent loss (tanδe=ε˝/εˊ) of epoxybased nano-Fe3O4/CFs composite as a diagram. These results show that the fabricated composite has exhibited both of the magnetic and dielectric losses. The measured ( ˊ) and ( ˝) of composite are 0.93 to 0.74 and 0.19 to -0.16, respectively and also its ( ˊ) and ( ˝) are 15.36 to 10.52 and 6.41 to 12.13, respectively. It is obvious that the tanδe value is higher than tanδm. This result indicates that the microwave attenuation of nano-Fe3O4/CFs composite is mostly attributed to dielectric losses rather than magnetic losses. This behavior can be related to the higher weight ratio of CFs in comparison with deposited nano-Fe3O4 particles and as well as the superior electrical conductivity of CFs (108 S/m at room temperature [34]). The conduction (eddy current)

losses and dielectric (dipolar) losses are known as the main dielectric loss mechanisms in nonmagnetic materials. Dipolar losses dominate in dielectric insulators, while conduction losses dominate in high conductivity materials such as CFs [35, 36]. It has been also found that the magnetic materials also can exhibit eddy current losses in addition of magnetic losses such as domain wall resonance, hysteresis and electron spin resonance. In this regard, due to existence of valance exchange conduction mechanism in Fe3O4 (for ferrites the conduction mechanism is electron hopping between ions of the same type on equivalent lattice sites, for example in magnetite this mechanism can be written as !" ↔ !" ), its electrical conductivity is relatively high (104 S/m at room temperature) [36-38]. Therefore, when it is exposed to EM radiation, the considerable amounts of eddy current losses are generated.
Based on the abovementioned discussions and results from measurements, it seems that the epoxy-based nano-Fe3O4/CFs composite benefits both of the dielectric and magnetic losses mechanisms and due to the electrically conductive nature of CFs and Fe3O4, it is logical that the main microwave attenuative source of nano-Fe3O4/CFs composite is dielectric loss.
3.6. Microwave absorption of epoxy-based nano-Fe3O4/CFs composites
In the case of an excellent microwave absorber composite, two requirements must be achieved. The first one has a good impedance matching condition which permits EM radiation to enter into the absorber appropriately and also avoids the high reflection (this requirement is considered as a prerequisite for microwave absorption). The second one has an excellent attenuation performance. Hence, the entered wave after interacting with microwave absorbing segments (in our case the nano-Fe3O4/CFs composite) of epoxy matrix composite, can be attenuated or strongly absorbed [35, 36]. Here, the absorption mechanism is based on the heating of absorber

It is clear that, the EMI SE of 2 mm sample is better than that for 1 mm sample and its average value is something about -23 dB. According to the equation (8), better EM attenuative properties can be obtained for the thicker composites with higher magnetic permeability and electrical conductivity [42-44]. In this regard, it has been reported that, the EMI SE of polymeric composites significantly depends on their thickness and also the intrinsic properties of their fillers [42]. Magnetic materials such as Fe3O4 [41, 42], MnFe2O4 [45, 46] and BaFe2O4 [44, 47] have been reported to improve the SE of polymer composites.

sections.heading: 4. Conclusion
sections.text:
A 3D structured nano-Fe3O4 deposited on CFs composite was successfully fabricated by a modified multi-step EPD method. The structural and chemical investigations revealed that the as-synthesized Fe3O4 powder has high crystallinity, purity, and very fine particle size (25 nm). The morphological studies showed that the nano-Fe3O4 particles have completely covered the surface of CFs.

metadata.abstractText: Recently, electromagnetic interference (EMI) shielding materials have absorbed a lot of attention due to a growing need for application in the area of electronic and wireless devices. In this study, a carbon-based EMI shielding composite was fabricated by electrophoretic deposition of Fe3O4 nano-particles on carbon fibers (CFs) as a 3D structure incorporated with an epoxy resin. Coprecipitation method was employed to synthesize Fe3O4 nano-particles. This as-synthesized Fe3O4 nano-powder was then successfully deposited on CFs using a modified multi-step electrophoretic deposition (EPD) method. The results of structural studies showed that the Fe3O4 nano-particles (25 nm) were successfully and uniformly deposited on CFs. The measured magnetic properties of as-synthesized Fe3O4 nano-powder and nano-Fe3O4/CFs composite showed that the saturation magnetization of bare Fe3O4 was decreased from Ms=72.3 emu/g to Ms=33.1 emu/g for nano-Fe3O4/CFs composite and also corecivity of Fe3O4 was increased from * Email: Mahdi.gholampoor@gmail.com, Tel.: +989194143530 Fax: +982188005040 M AN US CR IP T AC CE PT ED ACCEPTED MANUSCRIPT 2 Hc=4.9 Oe to Hc=168 Oe for composite. The results of microwave absorption tests revealed that the reflection loss (RL) of an epoxy-based nano-Fe3O4/CFs composite are significantly influenced by layer thickness. The maximum RL value of -10.21 dB at 10.12 GHz with an effective absorption bandwidth about 2 GHz was obtained for the sample with the thickness of 2 mm. It also exhibited an EMI shielding performance of -23 dB for whole the frequency range of 8.2-12.4 GHz.
